etymologies: early 18th century: from Italian portafogli, from portare ‘carry’ + foglio ‘leaf’ (from Latin folium)

definitions: a large, thin, flat case for loose sheets of paper such as drawings or maps

examples.text: under his arm he carried a large portfolio of drawings

shortDefinitions: large flat case for drawings etc.

definitions: a set of pieces of creative work collected by someone to display their skills, especially to a potential employer

examples.text: she had a portfolio of crayon portraits

shortDefinitions: set of pieces of creative work

definitions: a varied set of photographs of a model or actor intended to be shown to a potential employer

examples.text: entrants must not have done any professional modeling or have an existing portfolio

definitions: a range of investments held by a person or organization

examples.text: better returns on its investment portfolio

definitions: a range of products or services offered by an organization, especially when considered as a business asset

examples.text: an unrivaled portfolio of quality brands

definitions: the position and duties of a minister of state or a member of a cabinet

examples.text: he took on the Foreign Affairs portfolio

definitions: relating to, denoting, or engaged in an employment pattern that involves a succession of short-term contracts and part-time work, rather than the more traditional model of a long-term single job

examples.text: portfolio careers allow women to balance work with family

shortDefinitions: denoting employment pattern involving succession of jobs
